Either way regardless of what anyone says I think Rengar is overpowered and just a Kha'zix on steroids. Kha'zix can have a cool jump every once in a while, Rengar can jump halfway across the map for some reason with a 0 second cooldown and he's actually rewarded for doing it I believe. Kha'zix can slow you, Rengar will snare you for the next hour. Kha'zix has AoE damage that and single target damage that scales off AP and AD. Rengar will literally one shot your ADC and god forbid he ever decides to build more than a single AD item or you will never see your ADC for the rest of the game.

Both need massive kit reworks.
Though heaven knows when Riot will ever get to it.
Between the love/hate relationship that the community has with assassins, the overhaul on assassin kits is going to be polarizing to say the least.

Tell that to riot, I don't think they understand this concept.

thresh's strength is not his numbers. he could do 0 damage at all and still be good because he does everything. q is long range hook/stun and works as an initiation. w is shield and safety line. e is sweep and slow that stops channels and pulls or pushes opponents, whichever you want it to be. r is 99% slow. the damage is icing on the cake of DEATH

Lee's AS slow removal was HUGE. Part of his early game strength came from the AS's slow ability to give him an advantage in duels. 

Thresh's passive change from his Q to his E was also significant. It forces plays to either rank up Q for the cd, or E for the harass damage. It cut his power down dramatically.

If it's such a HUGE nerf, why is he still a top pick in LPL and LCK? He's never been nerfed "into the ground". He's ALWAYS been good. And if he is still fine in pro play after all of these nerfs, then doesn't that just say how crazy strong he was before the nerfs...?
Thresh can't be nerfed into irrelevance, his power doesn't come from numbers. Thresh's power comes from the sheer number of things he can do with his kit.

Thresh HAS been nerfed a lot over the past. He might be strong but there are plenty of other strong supports, such as {{champion:432}} , {{champion:201}} , {{champion:12}} , {{champion:89}} , {{champion:117}} , {{champion:99}} , {{champion:25}} , {{champion:16}}. Hell, the choice of support is a LOT more varied now than it ever was. Anyone with a modicum of CC can support, even if they weren't designed to ({{champion:111}}  is a key suspect)

Also, I feel a little insulted that Thresh is compared to {{champion:64}}  and {{champion:67}} . In his respective position, he's far, far less broken. And at the very least, he isn't getting buffed right now (not like Vayne got the Q buff that made it tons more forgiving if you do not the shot, or Lee getting the passive rework that makes it even easier to use AND the ultimate buff).
Well the difference is Thresh can't carry a game like Lee and Vayne. I think that has a lot to do with people thinking he's not as "OP" as they are.

But if he can't carry a game like Lee and Vayne can, then he literally isn't OP.
OP means overpowered, and the measure of power is how hard someone can carry a game. 

Even if you're a godlike Thresh, you're still reliant on your teammates to do the damage. It's not like {{champion:64}}  or {{champion:67}}  where they can reliably and easily 1v2 or even 1v3 by themselves. 

It's comparing carries that can delete characters in three shots or 4 button presses and a support that can at best hold someone down only for another person to deal that damage. At that point, it's a 2v1. But wouldn't the 1 person die faster if the support was ALSO a carry?

I'd like to call this Carrynomics.

I think you are looking at it a bit wrong. "OP" means you are over powered vs the same type. So an "OP" adc is going to be different than an "OP" tank. Supports can not carry, but one can be "OP" vs the others. And that's what Thresh is. He's just better in more ways than any other support. Some have higher strengths, but those that do have VASTLY more prominent weaknesses.
